meanings.def: to move to or towards a person or place
examples: + adv./prep. He left and said he was never coming back.
He came into the room and shut the door.
She comes to work by bus.
My son is coming home soon.
Come here!
Come and see us soon!
Here comes Jo! (= Jo is coming)
There's a storm coming.
come to do something They're coming to stay for a week.
He came towards me.
I hope you can come to Australia to visit us.
It's looks as if there's a storm coming.
When is your son coming home?

meanings.def: to arrive at or reach a place
examples: come to… They continued until they came to a river.
She came to work wearing a very smart suit.
They came as far as the gate.
People came from all over the country.
Your breakfast is coming soon.
Have any letters come for me?
Help came at last.
What time did you come (= to my house)?
People came from all over the world to settle here.
Let me know if any more mail comes.
He came to England by ship.
If you come late, the doctor may not be able to see you.

meanings.def: to arrive somewhere in order to do something or get something
examples: come for something I've come for my book.
come about something I've come about my book.
come to do something I've come to get my book.
come doing something He came looking for me.
I've come for those books you promised me.
I've come to see Mrs Cooper.

meanings.def: to move or travel, especially with somebody else, to a particular place or in order to be present at an event
examples: I've only come for an hour.
Thanks for coming (= to my house, party, etc.).
come to do something Ten thousand people came to hear him speak.
come to something Are you coming later?
come to something with somebody Are you coming to the club with us tonight?
come with somebody Come with me—I've got something to show you.
come doing something Why don't you come skating tonight?
Please come to my party on September 10th.
Are you coming to the theatre with us this evening?
I'm sorry, I won't be able to come.
Despite all the publicity, not many people came.
If you can't come to the meeting, let us know in advance.

meanings.def: to travel a particular distance
examples: We've come 50 miles this morning.
(figurative) The company has come a long way (= made lot of progress) in the last 5 years.
He's come all the way from Tokyo.
We've come a long way and we're very tired.
How far have you come?

meanings.def: to move in a particular way or while doing something else
examples: come doing something + adv./prep. A car came flying round the corner.
A huge wave came crashing over the sea wall.
(figurative) Questions came rushing into her head.
come doing something Don't expect me to come running every time you call.
The children came running into the room.
A crowd of men on horses carrying spears came charging down the road.

meanings.def: to happen
examples: The agreement came after several hours of negotiations.
The rains came too late to do any good.
Spring came late this year.
The time has come (= now is the moment) to act.
His first goal came in the 81st minute.
come as something His resignation came as no surprise.
Her death came as a terrible shock to us.
More details of the event are coming soon.
(informal) Come summer, people like to eat outdoors.
Dusk came quickly.
I never thought the day would come when I'd feel sorry for him.
The deadline came and went, but there was no reply from them.
Business improved as Christmas came nearer.
At last, the time came to leave.
When the moment actually came, I began to feel a little nervous.
He wanted to be buried beside her when the time came.
The time had come to let a younger person lead the party.
The high point of the concert came during the drum solo.
Come November, the high-season horror of traffic jams subsides.

meanings.def: used in questions to talk about how or why something happened
examples: How did he come to break his leg?
How do you come to be so late?

meanings.def: to have a particular position
examples: That comes a long way down my list of priorities.
She came second (= received the second highest score) in the exam.
His family comes first (= is the most important thing in his life).

meanings.def: used in many expressions to show that something has reached a particular state
examples: At last winter came to an end.
He came to power in 2019.
We need to come to an agreement on this issue.
When will they come to a decision?
our understanding of how the universe came into existence
The trees are coming into leaf.

meanings.def: to be available or to exist in a particular way
examples: come in something This dress comes in black and red.
come with something The DVD comes with several bonus features.
New cars don't come cheap (= they are expensive).
This luxury villa comes complete with its own private swimming pool.

meanings.def: to become
examples: + adj. The handle came loose.
The buttons had come undone.
Everything will come right in the end.
come to do something This design came to be known as the Oriental style.

meanings.def: to reach a point where you realize, understand or believe something
examples: In time she came to love him.
She had come to see the problem in a new light.
I've come to expect this kind of behaviour from him.

meanings.def: to have an orgasm
to be very clever, stupid, etc.
to play the part of a particular type of person; to behave in a particular way
examples: Don't come the innocent with me.

meanings.def: used to ask somebody to repeat something
examples: ‘She's an entomologist.’ ‘Come again?’ ‘An entomologist—she studies insects.’

meanings.def: to arrive and leave; to move freely
examples: They had a party next door—we heard people coming and going all night.

meanings.def: to be present for a short time and then go away
examples: The pain in my leg comes and goes.

meanings.def: to be easy, natural, etc. for somebody to do
examples: Acting comes naturally to her.

meanings.def: to be unsuccessful; to have no successful result
examples: How sad that all his hard work should come to nothing.
Her plans didn't come to anything.

meanings.def: used to introduce something extra that is connected with what has just been said
examples: I don't really trust him—nor his wife, come to that.

meanings.def: despite any problems or difficulties you may have
examples: He promised to support her come what may.

meanings.def: used to say you do not understand how something can happen and would like an explanation
examples: ‘I think you owe me some money.’ ‘How come?’
If she spent five years in Paris, how come her French is so bad?

meanings.def: to not be important or successful
in the future
examples: They may well regret the decision in years to come.
This will be a problem for some time to come (= for a period of time in the future).

meanings.def: when it is a question of something
examples: When it comes to getting things done, he's useless.

meanings.def: somebody’s ideas, beliefs, personality, etc. that makes them say what they have said
examples: I see where you're coming from (= I understand what you mean).

idioms.idiom: be as clever, stupid, etc. as they come
idioms.def: to be very clever, stupid, etc.
to play the part of a particular type of person; to behave in a particular way
examples: Don't come the innocent with me.

idioms.def: used to ask somebody to repeat something
examples: ‘She's an entomologist.’ ‘Come again?’ ‘An entomologist—she studies insects.’

idioms.def: to arrive and leave; to move freely
examples: They had a party next door—we heard people coming and going all night.
The pain in my leg comes and goes.

idioms.idiom: come easily, naturally, etc. to somebody
idioms.def: to be easy, natural, etc. for somebody to do
examples: Acting comes naturally to her.

idioms.idiom: come to nothing | not come to anything
idioms.def: to be unsuccessful; to have no successful result
examples: How sad that all his hard work should come to nothing.
Her plans didn't come to anything.

idioms.idiom: come to that | if it comes to that
idioms.def: used to introduce something extra that is connected with what has just been said
examples: I don't really trust him—nor his wife, come to that.

idioms.def: despite any problems or difficulties you may have
examples: He promised to support her come what may.

idioms.def: used to say you do not understand how something can happen and would like an explanation
examples: ‘I think you owe me some money.’ ‘How come?’
If she spent five years in Paris, how come her French is so bad?

idioms.def: to not be important or successful

examples: They may well regret the decision in years to come.
This will be a problem for some time to come (= for a period of time in the future).

idioms.def: when it is a question of something
examples: When it comes to getting things done, he's useless.

idioms.def: somebody’s ideas, beliefs, personality, etc. that makes them say what they have said
examples: I see where you're coming from (= I understand what you mean).

meanings.def: when the time mentioned comes
examples: They would have been married forty years come this June.
Come next week she’ll have changed her mind.

meanings.def: used when encouraging somebody to be sensible or reasonable, or when making a slight criticism
examples: Oh come now, things aren't as bad as all that.
Come, come, Miss Jones, you know perfectly well what I mean.

meanings.def: semen
